overview: This measure makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [8] It establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [8] The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [8]
appropriations: The legislative document specifies an appropriation out of the general revenues of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [8] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, and for the establishment of two temporary positions: one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist. [8] In testimony, the Judiciary submitted a three-year budget proposal for the pilot project totaling $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), indicating a funding shortfall for the third year of the program as the bill only appropriates funds for two years.
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's fiscal request is based on a detailed proposal for a three-year pilot project in the Kona division, which was updated from an initial two-year proposal to reflect the current version of the bill. The proposal accounts for the severe shortage of community-based mental health services on Hawai ªi Island by seeking funding for direct-provider positions and services. [7] [7] The budget also includes costs for staff training, technology, program evaluation, and various contracted services such as Moral Reconation Therapy and increased drug testing capabilities. [7]
agency_impact: The women's court pilot program will be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary and shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [8] This structure is intended to leverage the existing Big Island Drug Court staff and resources at the outset of the program. [7] The Department of Health anticipates providing support for the Kona pilot project and has requested positions including a 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist ($145,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)) and a 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV ($76,788 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)).
policy_impact: This measure has been substantially amended to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [9] It establishes a new three-year pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than in the Second and Fifth Circuits as originally proposed. [9] The requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study has been deleted and replaced with a requirement for the Judiciary to report on the need for pilot programs in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [9] [9]
revenue_sources: The appropriations for this measure are from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates funds for the first two years of a three-year pilot program in the Third Circuit, which sunsets on June 30, 2028. [8] [8] The legislative document specifies an appropriation of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2026-2027. [8] The Judiciary's updated testimony provides a full three-year budget request for the Kona Women's Court: $514,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 1, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 2, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Year 3. The total three-year request from the Judiciary is $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). While the bill's appropriation for FY 2026-2027 is slightly higher than the Judiciary's Year 2 request, there is no appropriation for the third year of the pilot, creating a projected shortfall of $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). The first-year budget from testimony requests funding for a Women's Mental Health Professional ($175,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), Womens Behavioral Health Beds ($100,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor ($85,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), a Cultural Practitioner and Advisor ($30,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), a Peer Specialist ($80,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), Moral Reconation Therapy ($25,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), Increased Drug Testing/Lab confirmation ($10,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), Training ($5,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)), and Technology ($4,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)). The second year budget includes funding for the Kona team to attend the All Rise National Conference at a cost of $42,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). The third year includes a cost of $10,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for program evaluation.
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary's budget proposal includes $4,900 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in technology costs for the first year of the program. [7] These costs cover a computer workstation in the probation waiting area ($1,200 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt)), a computer for the Kona Probation Supervisor ($1,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt)), a printer ($1,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt)), a cellphone ($500 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt)), and a laptop for work in rural communities ($1,200 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt)). [7] This technology is intended to support program operations and provide clients with reliable internet access for essential tasks. [7] [7]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The bill makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent, which will create ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year period. [8] The three-year women's court pilot program established in the third circuit Kona division is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [8] Any continuation or expansion of the Kona pilot program would require future legislative action and appropriations. [8]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure has been significantly amended since the previous fiscal note was issued. [9] Key changes include making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent and establishing a new three-year pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than in the Second and Fifth Circuits. [9] [9] The bill no longer requires an interim study for the Third Circuit but instead requires a report on the need for pilot programs in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division. [9] [9] Specific appropriations for the Kona pilot program have been inserted into the bill: $514,900 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_SSCR1240_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027, covering two of the pilot's three years. [9] In response to the amended bill, the Judiciary submitted an updated and detailed three-year budget proposal for the Kona pilot totaling $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).
